positive.review:
Total War: Shogun 2 is what happens when you mix tactical genius, samurai honor, and the constant urge to betray every alliance you’ve ever made because Kyoto looks too damn conquerable.

You play as the leader of a Japanese clan during the Sengoku period—an era where everyone was polite, poetic, and absolutely ready to stab you for rice and glory. It’s the perfect blend of grand strategy and real-time warfare: one minute you’re managing taxes and trade, the next you’re watching thousands of soldiers clash in misty valleys while you whisper, “Banzai.”

The battles? Stunning. Archers rain death, cavalry crash like thunder, and samurai carve through enemies with terrifying discipline. The sound of war drums, the clash of katanas, and that brief moment before the charge—it’s pure cinematic bliss. And if you mess up your flank? Congratulations, you just doomed your dynasty in 30 seconds flat.

Campaign mode is chef’s kiss: political marriages, ninja assassins, religious turmoil, and the classic Total War experience of accidentally angering every single neighbor because you “just took one more province.” The Realm Divide mechanic ensures your rise to power always ends in a beautiful storm of betrayal and blood.

Visually and mechanically, it’s aged like fine sake. It’s still one of the most balanced, atmospheric, and tactically satisfying entries in the series—proof that sometimes, less really is more.

10/10 – A Masterpiece of Strategy and Atmosphere

Total War: Shogun 2 stands as one of the greatest strategy titles ever made, perfectly blending deep turn-based empire management with breathtaking real-time battles. Set during Japan’s Sengoku Jidai era, the game captures the intensity, honor, and chaos of samurai warfare like no other.

The campaign map is beautifully crafted, every province feels meaningful, and decisions carry real weight. Diplomacy, economy, and military strategy are all balanced brilliantly, forcing players to think carefully instead of relying on brute force. When armies finally meet on the battlefield, the real-time combat is stunning—formations clash, arrows fly, and samurai warriors fight with cinematic intensity.

The atmosphere is unmatched: traditional Japanese music, gorgeous artwork, and immersive narration by Sun Tzu bring the world to life. Even more than a decade later, it remains visually impressive and technically smooth.

Whether you’re a Total War veteran or a newcomer, Shogun 2 delivers incredible depth, replayability, and emotional intensity. It’s a game where every victory feels earned and every defeat teaches a lesson.

A timeless classic and one of the finest strategy games ever made.

The best Total War. The base game is almost perfect. The Reign Divide and naval battles are the only weak points. Fall of the Samurai is even more impressive. It’s a strategy game where the start of the battle is more important than the battle itself. Terrain is everything, and having good units doesn’t automatically guarantee victory if you just charge into the enemy. Fast battles, difficult to micromanage the opposite of other games like Rome II, Attila, or even the newer ones like Warhammer 1, 2, and 3. CA is probably never going to achieve a remarkable game like this again. Fun, difficult, and sometimes unfair but not like Attila. It has the best multiplayer mode of all time, and sadly it was never reintroduced in another Total War, where you could create and customize your own faction and faction leader.

This is, in my opinion, the best total war game ever made. A bit lacking in variety, but the combination of elements from previous titles, alongside the narrower focus, allows this game to really soar. If you want to play Rome 2, the base game and DLC Rise of the Samuri get the same ideas right, and if you want to play Empire, there's no reason to play Empire anymore, because the Fall of the Samuri DLC does everything that game does and more. I was a bit iffy on my rankings until I played the DLC, but afterwards, this has quickly lept to one of my favorite strategy games of all time. Not to mention that the robust modding community that this game has, alongside steam workshop support, allows for a lot more once you're tired of the base game. Highly suggested from me, 8/10, only wish there was higher unit variety.

Excellent game; it comes with my high recommendation. For a strategy game, the learning curve is not overwhelming, and it has its charm and fun memes. Every clan you can play as has their unique advantages that incentivize the player into strategizing a certain way, so every clan feels different and fresh.

There are also plenty of resources available online that teach optimal strategy. MrSmartDonkey is a great channel for this. Just make sure to optimize your buildings, play to your clan's strengths, get the most out of your agents and out of diplomacy (as it's fairly lackluster in this game), encourage Town Growth (by keeping your taxes at Normal and having a healthy Food surplus), and don't trigger Realm Divide prematurely.

Of course, there are always things to nitpick. The Hattori special units are actually [i]worse[/i] than their vanilla counterparts, for example, but nothing game-breaking-ly bad.

No AI was used in the making of this review. Cheers.

This is a game where I have to use my real intelligence to win and destroy the enemy team. Both Shogun 2 and Fall of the Samurai A.I is no joke unlike other Total War series. They are really smart. Not only can they coldly calculate your movements and build up forces, but they can also surprise you with the huge army they have hidden away. 

In Fall of the Samurai, when I captured a Choshu coastal town, they counterattacked me with a force of 1,500, and I had no choice but to flee and retreat to nearby province. When they finally attacked, I was left with only 800 garrison troops and a wooden cannon unit for one final stand. I had to use all my brain power to defend and managed to destroy almost 1,500 of them and buy time for new reinforcements to arrive. 

Not only is it satisfying to win impossible battles against tough AI, but it also makes you feel proud of yourself to keep playing. This game doesn't give you free rewards you have to earn them with hard work and dedication. A masterpiece of all time.

A fantastic game, Shogun 2 is an example of pure strategy and satisfying lethality. I came from Warhammer and the learning curve is steep. If you want a strategy game where losing sight of a unit will cause them to die and you flank to crumble near instantly, this game is for you. Whether you are the dealer or the recipient, it is satisfying to watch an enemy line crumble with one move, and demoralising to see your army shatter because your general died.

If realism and brutally punishing gameplay is for you, then so is this game.

However, if you're after a casual walk in the park, a way to relax, or a game of war with fun mixes and matches of units, then this game is not for you. Unfortunately, I have been completely burnt out with this game, and even sitting in the menu I feel exhausted without even having booted up a campaign to play with friends. 

With a skill ceiling that crashes through the atmosphere and the level of perfection needed to ensure a smooth campaign, I'd recommend Total War Warhammer to anyone seeking a way to have fun and try out all sorts of interesting builds.

I want to give this game like a 3-4 stars but there's only yes or no, so I put no for some discontentment. This game could've been soooooo good but they f ed up some really crucial gameplay elements. First of all, naval warfare is so boring and there's so much of it and the AI has so many ships. It's impossible to maintain a navy that large and also an army that large. It makes no sense. If I maintain an army almost as big as the ai, I would be in the negative, never mind having a navy. The naval battle ai is also bugged so badly. In the two battles I fought, the ships just either ran away or didn't even move. There should've been some setting to disable it. 

Secondly, the campaign ai is so annoying. They almost never let me trade with them and they always work against me. This makes diplomacy so boring because there is virtually none. My neighbors will always attack me so all I do is attack them. I don't think I've ever been able to reach the end of the upgrade cycle. What's the point of all the mechanics like marriages and hostages? I had a lord give me his kid to maintain a trade agreement and literally next turn he rescinded and it said I executed his kid. Haha. He gave up his kids life for 260 koku I paid for the agreement. Come on.  

Lastly, realm divided is shit. It ruins the game. They expect me to invade a map that long just to have enemies from the other side sail over and land an army all the way behind me. Umm, it's economically impossible to maintain an army large enough to both invade forward and defend backwards. It takes like 3 turns to reach adjacent castles. On hard mode they would land an army with a full stack to invade. Even if I could win on a half stack against full stack, I can't keep 2-3 half stacks behind, that's too expensive. Especially because they nerf all the fun over powered tricks from shogun 1. Yea it was overpowered but that shit is fun as hell. In shogun 1, sometimes you can win a 1 vs 10 battle just because you cheese the terrain so hard. That was so satisfying. In shogun 2, terrain barely matters. Cavalry charge is weak. I remember in Medieval, a cavalry charge would destory an archer regiment. 

They could've had a perfect game but they ruined it.

Shogun is I believe the last OG Total War. While the AI is quite good, the game feels quickly repetitive. Because the game is set in feodal Japan, everyone share the same units; as a result the battles end up being a boring games of paper-stone-cisors with no surprises. Immobilize Spears with Katanas, charge from behind with cavalry, repeat x100. Other TW had more unit diversity, different biomes, various castle/city types, which allowed different gameplays as you encountered new factions. None of this here, the drill is always the same.

Another aspect is that the map uses already the "new" aspect, where it's not a real map but rather corridors between castles. The problem with this is that you don't have any "safe" rear, and depending how your map is set, you can be forced to campaign along a single axis. It forces you to overstretch yourself pretty quickly and play a game of cat-and-mouse, especially since upkeep is high and AI is aggressive on campaign mode.

Of course this is the normal gameplay; however I find it quickly tedious and lacking some of the lore/excitement that other TW could have.

Shogun is I believe the last OG Total War. While the AI is quite good, the game feels quickly repetitive. Because the game is set in feodal Japan, everyone share the same units; as a result the battles end up being a boring games of paper-stone-cisors with no surprises. Immobilize Spears with Katanas, charge from behind with cavalry, repeat x100. Other TW had more unit diversity, different biomes, various castle/city types, which allowed different gameplays as you encountered new factions. None of this here, the drill is always the same.

Another aspect is that the map uses already the "new" aspect, where it's not a real map but rather corridors between castles. The problem with this is that you don't have any "safe" rear, and depending how your map is set, you can be forced to campaign along a single axis. It forces you to overstretch yourself pretty quickly and play a game of cat-and-mouse, especially since upkeep is high and AI is aggressive on campaign mode.

Of course this is the normal gameplay; however I find it quickly tedious and lacking some of the lore/excitement that other TW could have.

I want to give this game like a 3-4 stars but there's only yes or no, so I put no for some discontentment. This game could've been soooooo good but they f ed up some really crucial gameplay elements. First of all, naval warfare is so boring and there's so much of it and the AI has so many ships. It's impossible to maintain a navy that large and also an army that large. It makes no sense. If I maintain an army almost as big as the ai, I would be in the negative, never mind having a navy. The naval battle ai is also bugged so badly. In the two battles I fought, the ships just either ran away or didn't even move. There should've been some setting to disable it. 

Secondly, the campaign ai is so annoying. They almost never let me trade with them and they always work against me. This makes diplomacy so boring because there is virtually none. My neighbors will always attack me so all I do is attack them. I don't think I've ever been able to reach the end of the upgrade cycle. What's the point of all the mechanics like marriages and hostages? I had a lord give me his kid to maintain a trade agreement and literally next turn he rescinded and it said I executed his kid. Haha. He gave up his kids life for 260 koku I paid for the agreement. Come on.  

Lastly, realm divided is shit. It ruins the game. They expect me to invade a map that long just to have enemies from the other side sail over and land an army all the way behind me. Umm, it's economically impossible to maintain an army large enough to both invade forward and defend backwards. It takes like 3 turns to reach adjacent castles. On hard mode they would land an army with a full stack to invade. Even if I could win on a half stack against full stack, I can't keep 2-3 half stacks behind, that's too expensive. Especially because they nerf all the fun over powered tricks from shogun 1. Yea it was overpowered but that shit is fun as hell. In shogun 1, sometimes you can win a 1 vs 10 battle just because you cheese the terrain so hard. That was so satisfying. In shogun 2, terrain barely matters. Cavalry charge is weak. I remember in Medieval, a cavalry charge would destory an archer regiment. 

They could've had a perfect game but they ruined it.
